snippet: In Andy Pettitte, , the Yankees have again turned to a great from the past, underscoring the franchise’s struggle to develop young starters.
abstract: Tyler Kepner On Baseball column asserts that the return of pitcher Andy Pettitte to New York Yankees underscores the franchise's struggle to develop young starters. (M)
lead_paragraph: For Brian Cashman, the call that changed the season came last Thursday while he was eating dinner with his children at a Chipotle restaurant in Darien, Conn. The Yankees' media relations director, Jason Zillo, told Cashman that Mariano Rivera had just been carted off the field at Kansas City. And so Cashman did what he always does when a Yankee is hurt: he assumed the worst and hoped for the best. A few hours later, the worst came true, with the diagnosis that Rivera had a torn anterior cruciate ligament and torn meniscus in his right knee. His season was over, but Cashman, the general manager, had perspective.

headline.main: Aging Savior Isn't What Yanks Need
